A Blackbox in the Car ?

US road planners are looking for a source of money to repair the declining highway system , and believe that they have found the solution in a small black box that can be found in the dashboard of any car .

The equipment that record every kilometre and report the information to the authorities is at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and state planning offices to revise the outdated system of financing US roads .
The normally rather boring area of road planning has suddenly sparked intense debate with colourful alliances .

Libertarians have allied themselves with environmental groups and argue that the government can use the small boxes to record the driven kilometres – and possibly where they were driven – and then use the information to calculate tax models .
The Tea Party is horrified .
The American Citizens ' Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and expresses a number of data protection concerns .
But , while Congress cannot agree on a course of action , several states no longer wait .
They are currently examining how they can switch over the next ten years to a system in which drivers pay per mile dri.
Thousands of drivers have already tested the tachographs , some of which are equipped with GPS monitoring .
This is really a must for our country .

“ It ’ s not something we will use only possibly , ” said Hasan Ikhrata , CEO of Southern California Assn. of Governments , who plans to record the driven miles for all Californian drivers in the state from 2025 onwards .
The way in which we pay these taxes will change .
The technology is there .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , financed from taxes paid by US Americans on the pillar , is broken .
But America no longer has as much tank as it used to be .
Cars consume less petrol .
The state oil tax of 18.4 cents per gallon ( less than 4 eurocents per litre ) has not increased for 20 years .
Politicians do not dare to raise the tax even by a cent at high injection prices .
“ The petrol tax is simply not future-oriented , ” said Lee Munnich , an expert in transport legislation at the University of Minnesota .
His state recently equiped 500 cars with tachographs to test a mile-based payment system .
“ This is the most sensible alternative in the long term , ” he said .
Bureaucrats call it a mile-based user fee .

It is not surprising that the idea appeals to urban liberals , because the tax could , for example , be used to influence driving behaviour in such a way as to reduce congestion and climate-damaging exhaust gases .
California ’ s planners rely on the system to develop strategies to achieve the state ’ s ambitious , legally enshrined targets on climate change .
But Republican Bill Shuster from Pennsylvania , chairman of the House Transportation Committee , has also said that he sees it as the most viable long-term alternative .
The free marketers of the Reason Foundation are also encouraged by the idea of having drivers pay on a journey back .
“ This is not a tax that disappears in a black hole , ” says Adrian Moore , Vice-President of Directives at Reason .
People pay directly for what they get .
The movement is also supported by two former US transport ministers who , in a 2011 report , called on Congress to move toward mile-based settlement .
Last year , the US Senate approved a $ 90 million pilot project involving 10,000 cars .

But the majority in the House of Representatives prevented the move , responding to the concerns of rural MEPs who represent people , who often have many miles on their way to work or to the city in their daily lives .
Nevertheless , several states and cities are moving in that direction on their own .
Oregon is the most committed driver , currently recruiting 5,000 drivers for the country .
These drivers will soon pay the mileage fees instead of the oil tax to the state .
Nevada has already completed a pilot project .
New York City is also considering such a thing .
Illinois tests it with lorries to a limited extent .

And the I-95 coalition , which includes the transport ministries of 17 states on the eastern coast ( including Maryland , Pennsylvania , Virginia , and Florida ) , is currently investigating how to introduce the change .
The concept is not a universal hit .
In Nevada , where 50 volunteers were recently equipped with the equipment , drivers were sceptical about the idea that the government could pursue each of its movements .
“ Concerns about Big Brother and such things were a big problem , ” explains Alauddin Khan , Head of Strategy and Earnings Management at Nevada ’ s Department of Transport .
People did not want it .
When the test started , Nevada ’ s ACLU warned on its website : “ It would be relatively easy to turn the tachograph into adult monitoring devices . ”
There is no need to build a gigantic , bulky technological infrastructure that would inevitably be used to collect data on the daily movements of individuals .
Nevada is part of a number of states that are now looking for affordable technology that allows the state to capture the driven kilometres , but not exactly when and where .
So , Khan said , the public would also be more reassured .
Hunting this technology has led some authorities to a small startup company called True Mileage in California .
The company was originally not involved in helping states to tax drivers .
Rather , it was their aim to take root in an emerging car insurance market , where drivers are to pay on the basis of the miles driven .
However , the devices it tested are also interesting for road planners , because they do not work with GPS and provide only limited information that is uploaded regularly by modem .
“ People are more willing to participate if their speed and locations are not recorded , ” said Ryan Morrison , Managing Director of True Mileage .
Some of these public pilot programmes have made major mistakes .
There are much cheaper and less intrusive ways to implement this .
In Oregon , planners are experimenting with giving drivers a range of choices .
You can choose a device with or without GPS .
Or they do not choose any equipment at all and instead pay a flat rate fee based on the miles passed on average by all residents of the state .
Others hope to be able to sell the concept of a distrustful public by equipping the equipment with more functions than with fewer .

In New York City , traffic officials want to develop a taxation device that can also pay parking fees , pay insurance only for driven kilometres and collect speed data from other vehicles in real time , thanks to which drivers can evade congestion .
“ Drivers would be motivated to participate by the added value of the benefits offered by the system , ” says a city planning document .
However , some transport planners wonder whether all the talk about paying per mile is not just a huge distraction .
At the Metropolitan Transportation Commission for the area of San Francisco Bay , officials said that Congress could solve the problem of bankrupt Highway Trust Fund simply by raising the fuel tax .
An additional one-off fee or annual levy could be imposed on drivers with hybrid vehicles or other vehicles that consume little petrol , so that they , too , pay a fair share .
“ There is no reason for an operation if an aspirin is sufficient , ” explains Randy Rentschler , the Commission ’ s Legislative and Public Affairs Director .

Esa decides on large space missions : missions for billions of dollars
Far planets , gravitational waves or black holes - European Space Agency experts now need to agree on two major projects they want to launch in the coming years .
30 proposals were available , five are still in the race .
Far worlds .
More than 1000 planets in other stars have already found astronomers .
No one knows whether there is life on at least some of them .
The choice is difficult : should you search for gravitational waves ?
Or would you rather explore the origin of the cosmos ?
Or fleeing for earth-like planets and thus perhaps discovering alien life ?
These questions are being asked by those responsible for the European Space Agency Esa .
For their " Cosmic Vision " programme , they are looking for ideas for two major space projects that will make a decisive contribution to research .
The budget for such ' L missions ' is approximately EUR 1 billion each .
The start is expected to be 2028 and 2034 .
In early September , the elite of European space research met in Paris to discuss proposals for such missions .
30 ideas were debated , five of which have now come into the closer election .
Numerous bodies examined the proposals and followed the researchers .
In the next few days , a final decision will be taken by the Scientific Programme Committee .
In total , the Esa has chosen four major questions to which the missions of the Cosmic Vision programme , initiated in 2007 , should be answered .
What are the conditions for the emergence of planets and life ?
The exact events in the emergence of stars from large gas clouds - and hence the emergence of planets surrounding these stars - are still in the proverbial dark .
A large infrared telescope in space could penetrate this dark .
And if a star owns a planet , under what circumstances can life arise there ?
In 2017 , the " Cheops " space telescope will be launched to investigate more closely the 500 already known planet systems in our neighbourhood .
But the possibilities are limited , Cheops is a small mission with a budget of EUR 150 million .

With larger instruments , astronomers could depict earth-like planets , even analyzing the composition of their atmospheres , seeking " biomarkers " : gases that are considered an indication of biological activity .
How does the solar system work ?
This question , too , is ultimately to provide information on the conditions for the emergence of life .
An important role is the magnetic activity of a star and the interaction of its magnetic field and the particle radiation from it with the planet system .
In our solar system , these processes can be examined in an example .
With the " Solar Orbiter " , the Esa has already approved a M-class mission ( there the budget is about half a billion euros ) for this issue .
The probe will start in 2017 and monitor the surface and activity of the sun closely .
Jupiter and his moons are also of great interest to researchers .
They want to find out what role the giant planet played in developing the solar system .
The Esa provides for the first of the three L-missions of the Cosmic Vision programme .
The probe " Juice " ( Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer ) is expected to start its journey in 2022 .
Eight years later , she reached Jupiter and was supposed to investigate the atmosphere of the planet and the icy moons of Europe , Kallisto and Ganymed .
What are the basic physical laws of the universe ?
Worldwide , there are many ways to study matter under extreme conditions and to investigate whether the laws of nature that we know are still valid there .
Perhaps there are deviations that could lead physicists to a new theory under which all known laws of nature can be united .
How did the universe emerge and what is it ?
13.7 billion years ago , our cosmos emerged from the big bang .

In addition to the matter we are familiar with , stars , planets and living beings like us , there are dark matter , whose gravity holds galaxies and clusters of galaxies together , and dark energy , which accelerates the expansion of space .
So far , researchers do not know which physical laws were valid in the first seconds of the Big Bang , nor what Dark Matter and Dark Energy consist of .
With " Euclid " , the Esa has already approved an M mission , which is scheduled to start in 2020 .

With a special telescope , the probe will examine the distribution of matter in the universe for the first time in the entire sky , thus enabling conclusions on the nature of dark matter and dark energy .
Who could make the race
Of the 30 proposals , only two will be left at the end of the selection procedure .
In the opinion of many experts " E-Lisa " , the best chances for gravitational waves are to be approved as an L mission .
These include physicists ’ changes in the structure of space time , which Albert Einstein predicted nearly 100 years ago .
They have not been proven to date .
Elisa could do that , hoping the scientists behind the project .
The mission provides for a detector consisting of two or three probes , which is stationed in space .
In contrast to plants on Earth , it could also prove gravitational waves created by the Big Bang , thus providing new insights into the formation of the cosmos .

Four other proposals still compete for the second L mission : a large X-ray telescope called " Athena " , which is to explore , among other things , black holes , " Icy Planets " , another mission to the outer planets of the solar system , " Prism " , a mission to measure the cosmic background radiation , and the " Exoplanet Finder " , which is to track and investigate earth-like planets .

E-mail is actually called an electronic letter .
Was the letter secret technically implemented when designing the Internet service ?

When user " Anna " sends an email to " Benni " , are the machines of the two connected directly ?
